title: 107_s1134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" and includes modifications applicable to qualified small business stock. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" includes amendments such as the repeal of minimum tax preference, an increase in the rollover period for qualified small business stock from 60 days to 180 days, and a reduction in the holding period for gains from certain small business stock. The "Venture Capital Gains and Growth Act of 2001" includes amendments like the repeal of minimum tax preference, an extended rollover period for qualified small business stock, and a shortened holding period for gains from certain small business stock from 5 years to 3 years. Additionally, the per-issuer limitation on taxpayer's eligible gain is repealed, and modifications are made to the definition of a qualified trade or business. (e) Qualified Trade or Business.--Section 1202(e)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include that the business is anticipated to continue. Section 1202(e)(6) is modified to extend the working capital period to 5 years. Additionally, an exception is added to the redemption rules for purchases with a business purpose. Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Additionally, a new provision allows a corporation to disregard stock purchases for tax purposes if a business purpose is established and avoiding limitations is not the primary goal. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code to reflect this change, including redesignating paragraphs and amending section headings. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a 100% exclusion for gains from certain small business stock. Amendments are made to exclude stock held by members of a controlled group and to make stock of larger businesses eligible for exclusion. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the asset limitation for qualified small businesses to $300,000,000. This adjustment applies to stock issued after 2002. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the asset limitation for qualified small businesses to $300,000,000 for stock issued after 2002. The adjustment is subject to a cost-of-living adjustment and rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. The effective date for these amendments is after the date of the enactment of this Act.
